mn8:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn8:3.3: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahācunda came out of solitude and went to the Buddha.
mn8:3.4: He bowed, sat down to one side,
mn8:3.6: “Sir, there are many different views that arise in the world
mn8:3.7: connected with doctrines of the self or with doctrines of the world.
mn8:3.8: How does a mendicant who is focusing on the starting point give up and let go of these views?”
mn8:4.1: “Cunda, there are many different views that arise in the world
mn8:4.2: connected with doctrines of the self or with doctrines of the world.
mn8:4.3: A mendicant gives up and lets go of these views by truly seeing with right wisdom where they arise, where they settle in, and where they operate as: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
mn8:5.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, might enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn8:5.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:5.5: they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.
mn8:6.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, might enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of convergence, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn8:6.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:6.5: they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.
mn8:7.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, with the fading away of rapture, might enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’.
mn8:7.5: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:7.6: they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.
mn8:8.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, might enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn8:8.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:8.5: they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.
mn8:9.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, might enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
mn8:9.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:10.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, might enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
mn8:10.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:11.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, might enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
mn8:11.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:12.1: It’s possible that a certain mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, might enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn8:12.4: But in the training of the noble one these are not called ‘self-effacement’,
mn8:14.1: Now, Cunda, you should work on self-effacement in each of the following ways.

mn8:51.1: ‘Others will be faithless, but here we will have faith.’

mn8:58.1: ‘Others will be attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, but here we will not be attached to our own views, not holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’
mn8:60.1: Cunda, I say that even giving rise to the thought of skillful qualities is very helpful, not to speak of following that path in body and speech.
mn8:60.2: That’s why you should give rise to the following thoughts. ‘Others will be cruel, but here we will not be cruel.’
mn8:60.3: ‘Others will kill living beings, but here we will not kill living beings.’ …
mn8:60.5: ‘Others will be attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, but here we will not be attached to our own views, not holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’
mn8:62.1: Cunda, suppose there was a rough path and another smooth path to get around it.
mn8:62.2: Or suppose there was a rough ford and another smooth ford to get around it.
mn8:62.3: In the same way, a cruel individual gets around it by not being cruel. An individual who kills gets around it by not killing. …
mn8:64.1: An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, gets around it by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.
mn8:66.1: Cunda, all unskilful qualities lead downwards, while all skilful qualities lead upwards.
mn8:66.2: In the same way, a cruel individual is led upwards by not being cruel. An individual who kills is led upwards by not killing …
mn8:66.4: An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, is led upwards by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.
mn8:68.1: Truly, Cunda, if you’re sinking down in the mud you can’t pull out someone else who is also sinking down in the mud.
mn8:68.2: But if you’re not sinking down in the mud you can pull out someone else who is also sinking down in the mud.
mn8:68.3: Truly, if you’re not tamed, trained, and extinguished you can’t tame, train, and extinguish someone else.
mn8:68.4: But if you’re tamed, trained, and extinguished you can tame, train, and extinguish someone else.
mn8:68.5: In the same way, a cruel individual extinguishes it by not being cruel. An individual who kills extinguishes it by not killing. …
mn8:70.24: An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, extinguishes it by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.
mn8:71.1: So, Cunda, I’ve taught the expositions by way of self-effacement, giving rise to thought, the way around, going up, and extinguishing.
mn8:71.2: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do for the benefit of their disciples.
mn8:71.3: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Cunda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
mn8:72.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn8:72.2: Uplifted, Venerable Mahācunda approved of what the Buddha said.
